CONCLUSION: Preliminary objection dismissed (application not properly submitted by the applicant but rather by a lawyer who claimed to be associated with the Helsinki Committee for Human Rights);Violation of P1-1;Remainder inadmissible;Pecuniary damage - financial award;Non-pecuniary damage - financial award;Costs and expenses partial award
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE .
CARDINAL . The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

CARDINAL . From DATE the applicant was employed by ORG ( “ the ORG ” ) , a ORG service . In DATE the ORG adopted new by - laws , which were approved by ORG . Under these by - laws , the ORG was registered as an independent legal person with the rights of a ORG company and governed by the ORG companies . It was created within the organs of local public administration and on the basis of municipal property but was financed exclusively from the income it generated from selling a variety of services to the local administration and to the population .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG decided to merge several bureaux , including ORG , into CARDINAL service at the County level . ORG thus became the legal successor of ORG in which the applicant had worked . Before this merger , ORG decided to reduce the number of personnel employed and as a result the applicant was made redundant by an order of CARDINAL DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE he acknowledged the dismissal notice in writing , as requested by law . In accordance with the relevant labour legislation , he requested redundancy payments ( namely redundancy compensation worth DATE average salary , his average DATE salary during DATE when he would be looking for a new job , payment for unused leave for DATE and payment of his salary for DATE and part of DATE ) .

CARDINAL . The employer refused to pay because it had set aside no money for redundancy payments . According to a certificate issued by the GPE employment office on DATE , the applicant had been unemployed from CARDINAL DATE to the date of the issue of the certificate .

CARDINAL . The applicant initiated court proceedings , claiming redundancy payments , namely DATE salary on dismissal , the continuing payment of his salary for DATE when he would be looking for another job and monetary compensation for untaken leave . On DATE ORG partly accepted his claims . He appealed and ORG quashed that judgment , ordering a full re - hearing of the case .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG rejected all his claims as unfounded .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG upheld that judgment . It found , among other things , that the applicant had missed the DATE deadline for making his claim against ORG , since the decision to reorganise the bureau had been published in DATE and the complaint had been lodged in DATE .

CARDINAL . Notwithstanding the fact that the applicant had missed the above - mentioned time - limit , on DATE ORG examined the substance of his appeal and upheld the judgment of ORG . The court reasoned that no compensation was due because ORG , in which the applicant had worked , was self - financed ; it had not set aside any resources for compensation but had distributed all the money obtained from its activity to its employees , after paying taxes . Since it had been an independent legal person , its legal successor , ORG , could not be held liable for any outstanding debts . The court also found that the applicant had not offered any new services after DATE and thus could not claim his salary for DATE . He had been warned in DATE of impending dismissal and instructed to complete all outstanding work by DATE . Finally , the court found that he had not registered with the ORG employment office as unemployed and could therefore not claim redundancy compensation .
CARDINAL . The relevant provisions of LAW of DATE , in force until DATE , read as follows .
“ Article CARDINAL . NORP Sphere of application of labour legislation .

The labour legislation regulates work relations of employees employed in enterprises , institutions and organisations on the territory of GPE , regardless of the type of property and form of management ...
Article CARDINAL . Nullity of contract clauses making the conditions of employees worse .
ORG clauses making the conditions of employees worse than those provided for by law are null and void .
Article CARDINAL/CARDINAL . Indemnities and compensation for employees made redundant .
Employees made redundant by enterprises , institutions and organisations because of a reduction of the number of personnel or status of personnel :
CARDINAL ) NORP shall be paid a redundancy indemnity worth DATE average salary ;

CARDINAL ) NORP shall continue to receive the average salary during the period needed to find a new job , but for no longer than DATE from the date of redundancy , taking into account the payment of the redundancy indemnity ;

CARDINAL ) NORP exceptionally , shall continue to receive the average salary during DATE from DATE of redundancy , based on a decision of the employment office , subject to the employee 's timely request to that authority ( within DATE of redundancy ) and if not offered a job in the meantime .
LAW Prohibition of granting of monetary compensation in lieu of untaken leave
It is prohibited to grant monetary compensation in lieu of untaken leave , save in the case of dismissal of an employee who has not used his or her leave DATE ” .
CARDINAL . The relevant provisions of LAW ( in force until DATE ) read as follows :
“ Article CARDINAL . Scope of appeal proceedings .

The court which examines the appeal shall verify whether the first - instance court 's judgment is lawful and well - grounded , on the basis of the information in its possession , as well as any new written evidence submitted to the court .
The court may re - evaluate the evidence in its possession and examine any new evidence submitted by the parties in accordance with the present Code .
The court shall deal with each ground of appeal invoked . ”
